Sport is not exempt, it must tackle climate change too

16/11/2021

Lucy Wilde argues sport is also responsible for making the planet more sustainable, following COP26

Image by IMAGE: LAT PHOTOGRAPHIC

By Lucy Wilde

While these athletes made no claim towards scientific expertise, using sport as an avenue through which to explore such a monumental social issue has the potential to be extremely effective.

Sport is not immune from the responsibility of reducing emissions.

The elevated status of these athletes as super-human, unfalteringly adept at achieving whatever they set their minds to, may need reconsidering. The classic dichotomy of â€˜usâ€™ and â€˜themâ€™, applicable across a multitude of societal fractions, is perhaps unhelpful when it comes to climate activism.

Politicians; world leaders; corporate directors; investors; athletes; rights holders, to name a select few of the parties considered influential when it comes to climate policy. While this is in part true, the â€˜ordinaryâ€™ among us have a significant role to play too.

The fact that sport was recognised as an official forum of discussion at this yearâ€™s COP suggests there has been at least some consideration of its power to influence action on climate change.

The historic disjunction between sport and climate discussions has been broken, as 150 athletes, sports teams and related sports organisations, have joined forces to endorse a COP26 Sports Community Manifesto. Developed by EcoAthletes, a non-profit that â€˜inspires and coaches athletes to lead climate actionâ€™, the #ClimateComeback is at the heart of the initiative.

The final message of the manifesto in particular, left a lasting impression on me: â€œthe #ClimateComeback is necessary for humanity...we owe no less to ourselves, our youth, and the future of our sport. This is a game we can and must win.â€

The sporting spirit of summer 2021 was arguably encapsulated by the rise of young stars. The frenzy caused by Raducanuâ€™s storm to US Open champion knew no bounds. Only ensuring the future survival of the planet can allow summers to come to compare.

While doubtlessly certain sports have made huge strides towards reducing their carbon, such as Formula Eâ€™s carbon-neutral status, others must catch on and catch up.

Plainly, an exposition of how the current climate crisis has, and will continue to affect sport might open the everyday readerâ€™s (and sports fanâ€™s) eyes to the role of sport in all this.

Sport intersects with society: extreme weather showed face at the Tokyo Olympics and continues to have impacts across the world, from school league to global competitions. The 2022 World Cup in Qatar alone is expected to create 3.6 million tonnes of carbon dioxide - more than some nations produce in an entire year.

The Climate Coalition revealed up to 62,500 amateur matches are cancelled or postponed in the UK, while on average, grass-roots clubs lose five weeks of every season to inclement weather. This data exemplifies the scale of impact across sporting platforms.

Young athletes are the future of sport, but their future success is mutually reliant on the future condition of our planet.

At the recent COP,Â  much was done to instil a sense of guardianship towards the younger generation and the issues they will face due to our delay in addressing our planet's needs. Planet SuperLeague presented a spin off, CUP26, to Cambridge United for their younger fans. A simple knockout competition encouraged broader engagement - key in mobilising change.

According to a BBC Sport study, 2050 is set to see almost one in four English Football grounds subject to annual flooding as a result of sea-level rises.

Nor is climate change merely an international threat. Carlisle United can attest to this since their Brunton Park ground has flooded twice since 2005.

The viability of sport is at stake.

The diversity of impact across sports sectors, at local and wider level, also raises the theme of social justice. The intersectionality of sport with other social issues allows for a clearer recognition of the disproportionate effects of climate change on smaller, regional clubs, and their members.

Global Citizen captured this well when they announced that: â€œBlack and Indigenous people are disproportionately experiencing the impacts of climate change:Â  flooded homes, vanishing sources of drinking water, disrupted local economies, extreme heat waves.â€

The infrastructures around mainstream sport remain disproportionately controlled by the global north and middle-class majority.

Yet sportâ€™s role in climate action doesnâ€™t need to follow suit. Sport can be a catalyst for a more diverse movement, where decisions are made with a cross section of societyâ€™s best interests at heart.

A fundamental basis of sport - honing a firm sense of togetherness - is a transferable quality in matters of climate action.

As we look forward, following COP26, there is cause for optimism.

The UN has announced 46 new signatories to a new tier of its Sport for Climate Action Framework. Those who sign are bound to cut carbon emissions in half by 2030, be net zero by 2040, and disclose publicly their progress towards these goals.

The existence of this process, with its emphasis on public transparency, is no doubt a step in the right direction. However 251 signatories to the original framework have failed to commit their names to paper.

If the football industryâ€™s purported footprint really does amount to the size of countries such as Spain, COP26 has also served as an unyielding reminder of the work that still remains to be done.
